prompt: Extreme macro photograph focusing sharply on the heavily worn tang stamp of a very old, rusted pocket knife blade. The stamp, barely legible, might read 'KA-BAR'. The surrounding steel shows significant pitting, patina, and age marks. The knife rests on a dark, cracked leather surface. Dramatic, low-key side lighting highlights the texture of the metal and the indentations of the stamp. The background is deeply blurred. Ultra-realistic detail, capturing the essence of age and history. Landscape orientation (16:9) with the blade extending horizontally.
name: old-pocket-knives-identification-image-2.png

prompt: A clean, professional flat lay composition showcasing a diverse lineup of five different classic pocket knife patterns (e.g., Trapper, Stockman, Peanut, Congress, Whittler) arranged horizontally across a textured, neutral grey background. Each knife features distinct handle materials like stag, jigged bone, smooth yellow composite, and dark wood. Blades are partially open to show different configurations. Even, bright studio lighting ensures clarity and accurate color representation. Sharp focus throughout. Ideal for illustrating pattern identification guides. Wide 16:9 aspect ratio.
name: old-pocket-knives-identification-image-3.png

prompt: Close-up, slightly angled overhead shot focusing on the intricate details and varied textures of three different antique pocket knife handles laid partially overlapping on a piece of aged, dark burlap fabric. One handle is genuine mother-of-pearl showing iridescent shimmer, another is deeply jigged dark bone, and the third is a cracked ice celluloid pattern. Warm, directional lighting from the top right creates subtle shadows, emphasizing the textures and imperfections. Shallow depth of field, photorealistic rendering. Composition fills the 16:9 frame with tactile detail.
name: old-pocket-knives-identification-image-4.png

prompt: Side-by-side comparison shot illustrating knife condition: two similar vintage pocket knives (e.g., Camillus Stockman) are placed parallel horizontally against a simple, slightly out-of-focus rustic wood background. The knife on the left is in 'near mint' condition – clean, sharp blades, intact handles, strong snap. The knife on the right shows heavy wear – significant blade loss from sharpening, patina, cracked handle scales, maybe a broken spring. Clear, neutral studio lighting highlights the differences starkly. Focus is sharp on both knives. Photorealistic style for valuation context. 16:9 widescreen format.
name: old-pocket-knives-identification-image-5.png
